cards.title: Man Utd / Club yet to make formal approach for Coleman
cards.rawTitle: Club yet to make formal approach for Coleman

item.title: Manchester United yet to make formal approach for Everton’s Seamus Coleman
item.trailText: Manchester United are yet to make a formal approach to sign Seamus Coleman from Everton but the Republic of Ireland defender does feature on the club’s shortlist of potential summer signings
item.standFirst:
• Ireland right-back is on Louis Van Gaal’s shortlist of transfer targets
• Coleman signed a new five-year contract last summer
item.body:
Manchester United are yet to make a formal approach to sign Seamus Coleman from Everton but the Republic of Ireland defender does feature on the club’s shortlist of potential signings.

Reports over the weekend stated that manager Louis Van Gaal has identified the 26-year-old as his primary target to fill the troublesome right-back position. However, it is understood that United have not approached Everton to discuss whether they would be open to selling a player purchased from Sligo Rovers in 2009 for just £60,000.

Coleman signed a new five-year contract at Goodison Park last June after speculation that he was a target for United having been selected in the PFA team of the year for the 2013–14 season.

The Donegal-born defender struggled to replicate that form last season after suffering injuries early on but Everton are expected to resist any attempts to prise him away, with the club thought to value Coleman at around £20m.

United have been searching for a specialist right-back to fill the position after Antonio Valencia spent much of last season filling in. They were interested in signing Dani Alves until the Brazil defender decided to stay with Barcelona, while Van Gaal opted not to follow through on interest in Southampton’s Nathaniel Clyne, who is expected to have a medical on Monday ahead of his £12.5m move to Anfield.

Guillermo Varela, who was David Moyes’s first signing as United manager and spent last season playing for Real Madrid’s Castilla team under Zinedine Zidane, may yet be given the opportunity to push for a first-team place on the forthcoming tour to the USA.

Reports in France have also stated that United are interested in signing Lille’s Malian midfielder Adama Traoré but will face competition from Manchester City and Chelsea. Traoré was voted the best player at the recent Under-20 World Cup as he helped his country finish third.

displayImages.caption: Seamus Coleman joined Everton from Sligo Rovers in 2009 for just £60,000. Photograph: Robbie Stephenson/JMP/REX
displayImages.cleanCaption: Seamus Coleman joined Everton from Sligo Rovers in 2009 for just £60,000. Photograph: Robbie Stephenson/JMP/REX

cards.title: Paraguay / Uncle of González dies celebrating nephew’s winning penalty
cards.rawTitle: Uncle of González dies celebrating nephew’s winning penalty

item.title: Uncle of Paraguay’s Derlis González dies celebrating nephew’s winning penalty
item.trailText: The uncle of Derlis González, who scored Paraguay’s winning penalty in the Copa América quarter-final against Brazil, died of a heart attack while celebrating the victory, it has been reported
item.standFirst:
• Irrazábal Manuel suffered a heart attack watching Copa América match
• Paraguay beat Brazil 4-3 on penalties to reach semi-final
• Beauty leaves the Brazilian game as glitter gives way to grit
item.body:
The uncle of Derlis González, who scored Paraguay’s winning penalty in the Copa América quarter-final against Brazil, died of a heart attack while celebrating the victory, it has been reported.

Related: Mother of Leicester winger Marc Albrighton’s partner killed in Tunisia massacre

FC Basel midfielder González scored Paraguay’s penalty in normal time before taking his chance from the spot to secure a famous victory over the five-time world champions in Concepción. However, his delight was short-lived after being informed that his uncle Irrazábal Manuel had passed away after watching the match at his home in Paraguay.

“Why today uncle? Why? You left me after a heart attack because I gave you so much joy and so much happiness. I can’t believe it,” González wrote on Twitter.

“He’s my friend, I consider my brother, my cousin’s husband was,” González’s father Simon told Paraguayan newspaper Ultima Hora.

Paraguay are due to face Argentina in the semi-finals on Tuesday.

displayImages.caption: Derlis González's uncle suffered a heart attack after the Copa América quarter-final. Photograph: Miguel Tovar/STF/LatinContent/Getty Images
displayImages.cleanCaption: Derlis González's uncle suffered a heart attack after the Copa América quarter-final. Photograph: Miguel Tovar/STF/LatinContent/Getty Images

headerImage.caption: Derlis González's uncle suffered a heart attack after the Copa América quarter-final. Photograph: Miguel Tovar/STF/LatinContent/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Derlis González's uncle suffered a heart attack after the Copa América quarter-final. Photograph: Miguel Tovar/STF/LatinContent/Getty Images

cards.title: England / Under-17s head coach Peacock leaves FA to join Derby
cards.rawTitle: Under-17s head coach Peacock leaves FA to join Derby

item.title: England Under-17s head coach John Peacock leaves FA to join Derby
item.trailText: The England Under-17s head coach, John Peacock, has announced he will be leaving the Football Association after a career spanning a total of 21 years to return to Derby
item.standFirst:
• Peacock leaves FA after 21 years in two spells at governing body
• 59-year-old returns to Derby as Paul Clement’s first-team coach
item.body:
The England Under-17s head coach, John Peacock, has announced he will be leaving the Football Association after a career spanning a total of 21 years to return to Derby.

The 59-year-old, who previously worked for the Rams as the academy director, rejoins the club as first-team coach to work alongside the newly-appointed manager Paul Clement. Peacock admitted the decision to leave the FA was a tough one to make but he is relishing a new challenge at the Championship club.

He said: “This has been one of the most difficult decisions I have had to take. Leaving an organisation like the FA where it has so many outstanding individuals has not been easy. It has been an absolute privilege to work here for two spells spanning a total of 21 years.

Related: Derby County appoint Paul Clement as new head coach

“Developing so many talented young elite players through the England international youth teams programme these past 13 years has been an amazing experience. We have very talented players in this country and to play a small part in their development has been challenging and extremely rewarding for me personally.

“It is in respect of a further challenge which has subsequently taken me towards making this difficult decision. The last 25 years of my working life has been spent with the FA and Derby County FC.

“The chance to work once again at this fantastic club, which has an outstanding infrastructure and above all else highly passionate supporters and board of directors who have an ambition for success, meant the challenge of re-joining as first team coach was an opportunity I couldn’t decline.

“Finally, it is always refreshing to see an English coach succeed. Furthermore it is even more difficult for this to happen abroad. In Paul Clement we have this person after his successful spells at Chelsea, Paris Saint-Germain and, of course, Real Madrid.

“I was delighted when Paul offered me this opportunity to assist him in his role as the head coach of Derby County FC. I am really looking forward to the next chapter in my coaching career.”

In his time at the FA, Peacock has led the Under-17s to two European Championship titles in 2010 and 2014, and has managed over 100 games in Uefa competition, with a 69% win record.

He added: “I leave the FA on a positive note having just qualified once again for the Fifa Under-17 World Cup in Chile in October – I wish all the players and staff every success.”

As a player, Peacock spent seven seasons with Scunthorpe in which he played more than 200 league and cup games. The FA technical director, Dan Ashworth, said: “We will sorely miss John and I can only thank him for his contribution to The FA and England, both as a coach and a coach educator.

“His record speaks for itself and Derby County have a fine coach to supplement the work of Paul Clement. On behalf of everyone The FA I would like to wish John well – he leaves behind a great legacy through his work.”

displayImages.caption: John Peacock, who has spent 21 years at the FA in two different spells, joins Paul Clement's coaching staff at Derby. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.cleanCaption: John Peacock, who has spent 21 years at the FA in two different spells, joins Paul Clement's coaching staff at Derby. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

cards.title: World Cup 2022 / Spanish league challenges Fifa over switch in dates
cards.rawTitle: Spanish league challenges Fifa over switch in dates

item.title: Spanish league challenges Fifa over switch in 2022 World Cup dates
item.trailText: The Spanish football league is challenging Fifa’s decision to switch the 2022 World Cup in Qatar to November-December
item.standFirst:
• League file appeal with Cas over move to winter months in Qatar
• Switch will force European leagues to shut down in mid-season
item.body:
The Spanish football league is challenging Fifa’s decision to switch the 2022 World Cup in Qatar to November-December.

The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) says the Spanish league (LFP) has filed an appeal against the Fifa decision, which would mean the tournament avoids the Qatari summer heat.

But a November-December tournament would also force top European leagues to shut down for eight peak weeks and require more summer fixtures.

This is the first formal legal challenge to moving the World Cup in Qatar from the traditional June-July slot. The court has not set a hearing date.

Fifa’s executive committee approved the change in March, 18 months after requesting a global consultation. The Spanish league is a member of the European Professional Football Leagues group, which was consulted.

Fifa rejected a proposal by European clubs and leagues to play in May-June.

The Spanish sports newspaper As quoted the LFP president, Javier Tebas, as saying he had filed the lawsuit “in defence of the interests of the clubs that are contributing to the international teams”.

According to As, Tebas submitted three independent expert reports to Cas which concluded the LFP would lose €65m (£24.5m) by moving the World Cup to the winter.

displayImages.caption: Javier Tebas, president of the Spanish League, has submitted three independent reports to Cas which concluded the LFP would lose €65m euros (£24.5m) by moving the 2022 World Cup to the winter. Photograph: Dave Thompson/Getty Images

cards.title: Copa América / Jara hit with three-game ban for Cavani incident
cards.rawTitle: Jara hit with three-game ban for Cavani incident

item.title: Chile’s Gonzalo Jara out of Copa América semi-final with three-game ban
item.trailText: Chile defender Gonzalo Jara has been handed a three-match ban for provoking Uruguay’s Edinson Cavani in Copa América quarter-final
item.standFirst:
• Former Forest man provoked Uruguay’s Edinson Cavani in quarter-final
• Jara feigned injury when Cavani reacted and the striker was sent off
item.body:
Chile’s Gonzalo Jara has been suspended for three matches for provoking Uruguay’s Edinson Cavani during their 1-0 Copa América quarter-final victory.

The former West Bromwich Albion and Nottingham Forest defender will miss the semi-final against Peru as Chile seek to win the tournament for the first time in its 99-year history.

Jara came up behind Cavani and poked him in the backside. The Uruguay forward reacted by raising his hand toward Jara’s head and the Chilean collapsed feigning injury. The referee missed Jara’s provocation and sent off Cavani.

displayImages.caption: Gonzalo Jara will now be a spectator as Chile attempt to win a first Copa América title. Photograph: Claudio Reyes/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Gonzalo Jara will now be a spectator as Chile attempt to win a first Copa América title.

cards.title: Women's World Cup 2015 / Iwabuchi winner worth the wait for Japan
cards.rawTitle: Iwabuchi winner worth the wait for Japan

item.title: Mana Iwabuchi winner worth the wait for Japan in Women’s World Cup
item.trailText:
• Bayern Munich striker comes off bench to beat Australia
• Norio Sasaki’s side to stay in Edmonton for England clash
item.standFirst:
• Bayern Munich striker comes off bench to beat Australia
• Norio Sasaki’s side to stay in Edmonton for England clash
item.body:
Japan’s coach Norio Sasaki could not resist making a joke at Mana Iwabuchi’s expense when explaining his decision to bring on the forward during the second half of their 1-0 quarter-final win against Australia on Saturday in the Women’s World Cup quarter-finals.

The Bayern Munich forward scored after a scramble in front of goal in the 87th minute. But her introduction 15 minutes earlier could have hit a snag due to a communication breakdown.

“Her first name is Mana. And in Japanese ‘Not yet, not yet,’ would be ‘mada’ so [the words] are very close,” Sasaki said through a translator. Once Iwabuchi realised she was needed right away, the course of the match was about to change.

Now Japan will stay in Edmonton, where they will play England in their semi-final on Wednesday.

Patience and fresh legs paid off for the defending champions as their ball-controlling style combined with the 90F temperature gradually wore down the 10th-ranked Australians.

Iwabuchi, 22, had nearly scored a minute earlier but her shot was blocked by Elise Kellond-Knight, which led to a corner. Though Aya Miyama’s set piece was headed out of the area, the ball bounced directly to Rumi Utsugi, who immediately sent it back towards goal. Azusa Iwashimizu had her shot stopped by Lydia Williams, but the goalkeeper was unable to control the rebound. The ball flew to the left, where Iwabuchi knocked it into the empty net.

Japan have won four of their past five meetings with their quarter-final rivals, and their superiority was evident.

Yet Australia did a better job than Japan’s previous opponents in bottling up the middle and pressuring the ball carrier to disrupt their crisp, short-passing style. In the first half, Samantha Kerr was bundled over by Iwashimizu, who was booked. Alanna Kennedy took the resulting free-kick but curled her shot well wide of a post.

But the Japanese attack wore down Australia in the second half. In the 77th minute, Saori Ariyoshi broke free up the middle only to have her shot blocked by Kellond-Knight. Then came Iwabuchi’s moment of glory.

“The difficulty was the heat,” said Utsugi. “Throughout the game, the resolve of all members to keep it up to the end was the challenge. However, we did manage to do that.”

Japan have been victorious in all five of their matches in Canada and have won eight in a row since winning the 2011 tournament in Germany, where they beat the USA on penalties in the final.

The Japanese are two victories from becoming the second nation to win consecutive tournaments after Germany triumphed in 2003 and 2007.

Australia go home after completing their best run in tournament history. Australia won their first elimination game by upsetting seventh-ranked Brazil in the round of 16. “Obviously disappointed at the result, but when you look at the big scheme of things, we lost 1-0,” the coach, Alen Stajcic, said. “It was 1-0 in the 87th minute off a scrappy corner. It’s not as if we were humiliated.”

They were, however, beaten by a team who showed more composure and patience. Australia exerted too much energy chasing the ball in the first 20 minutes. And when they finally got possession, they too often gave the ball away.

“Certainly Japan were a lot more composed throughout the 90 minutes,” Stajcic said. “It’s a heart-breaking experience for all of us. But sometimes you learn the most from these experiences.”

Sasaki was pleased with how his team kept going following several missed chances. “I was thinking that even if we didn’t have a goal in 90 minutes, we would certainly do that by 120 minutes,” he said. “While we do recognise the growth of Australia, I think the result has given confidence to the Japanese players.”

displayImages.caption: Mana Iwabuchi, right, celebrates scoring the winner against Australia in the Women’s World Cup.  Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Getty Images
displayImages.cleanCaption: Mana Iwabuchi, right, celebrates scoring the winner against Australia in the Women’s World Cup.  Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Getty Images

headerImage.caption: Mana Iwabuchi, right, celebrates scoring the winner against Australia in the Women’s World Cup.  Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Getty Images
headerImage.cleanCaption: Mana Iwabuchi, right, celebrates scoring the winner against Australia in the Women’s World Cup.  Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Getty Images

cards.title: Besiktas / Ba set to leave for Chinese side Shanghai Shenhua
cards.rawTitle: Ba set to leave for Chinese side Shanghai Shenhua

item.title: Demba Ba set to join Chinese side Shanghai Shenhua from Besiktas
item.trailText: Demba Ba has arrived in China to complete his move to Shanghai Shenhua for what is expected to be a record transfer fee believed to be around £11m
item.standFirst:
• Former Chelsea striker expected to cost around £11m
• Ba due to have medical on Sunday before completing move
item.body:
Demba Ba has arrived in China to complete a move to Shanghai Shenhua for what is expected to be a record transfer fee of around £11m.

The Senegal striker, who left Chelsea to join Besiktas last July having also spent 18 months at Newcastle, was due to have a medical after being pictured being mobbed by supporters at the airport. It is understood that the 30-year-old Ba turned down an approach from West Bromwich in order to join the club where Didier Drogba spent eight months in 2012.

Shenhua made the announcement on their website on Saturday but did not confirm the fee. They already have the former Everton forward Tim Cahill on their books and signed the Mali midfielder, Mohamed Sissoko, on a free transfer from Levante last week.

displayImages.caption: Demba Ba reportedly rejected interest from West Brom to move to China. Photograph: Tolga Bozoglu/EPA
displayImages.cleanCaption: Demba Ba reportedly rejected interest from West Brom to move to China. Photograph: Tolga Bozoglu/EPA
